result: Plan for CC[C@@H](OC(=O)c1ccccc1)[C@H]1CCCN(C(=O)OC(C)(C)C)C1: strategy_index='1' core_structure_analysis='The molecule is built on an N‑Boc‑protected pyrrolidine (five‑membered tertiary amine) that is substituted at the C2 position by a chiral secondary carbon. That stereocenter bears an n‑propyl group and an oxygen functioning as a benzoyl ester (PhC(=O)O–). The pyrrolidine + its C2 substituent form the topologically central scaffold (a 2‑substituted pyrrolidine bearing a benzoate‑masked secondary alcohol).' strategic_bond_disconnection='Disconnect the ester C(=O)–O bond that links the benzoyl group to the secondary oxygen (break PhC(=O)–O–CH stereocenter). This gives two simple precursors: the benzoyl electrophile (PhCOCl or PhCOOH) and the chiral 2‑(hydroxy)‑substituted pyrrolidine (the C2 secondary alcohol on the pyrrolidine scaffold).' reaction_type='Acylation / esterification (formation of an ester from an alcohol and an acyl electrophile).' reaction_name='Benzoylation (acylation) — e.g., Schotten–Baumann or DCC/DMAP mediated esterification (or use of benzoyl chloride).' description='Breaking the benzoate ester is the highest‑value disconnection because it separates a protecting/derivatizing acyl group from the chiral aminoalcohol core, greatly reducing complexity. Chemically, this corresponds to preparing the target by benzoylation of the preformed chiral 2‑hydroxy‑substituted pyrrolidine (the tertiary amine can be Boc‑protected or free during or after the step). Practically one would synthesize the C2‑substituted pyrrolidine bearing the free secondary alcohol (from e.g. nucleophilic substitution on a 2‑halo pyrrolidine or by asymmetric addition to a suitable precursor), then install the benzoyl group using benzoyl chloride (or PhCOOH with DCC/DMAP) to give the observed benzoate. Boc installation/removal on nitrogen is a separate, straightforward protection/deprotection step.'

Plan for O=C(N[C@@H]1C(=O)N2[C@@H]1SC([C@@H]2C(=O)O)(C)C)COc1ccccc1: strategy_index='1) Disconnect the N‑acyl (amide) bond — retrosynthetic transform: amide disconnection to 6‑APA and phenoxyacetyl chloride/acid. Rationale: the N‑acyl bond is an obvious late‑stage substituent (easy to install selectively in forward synthesis by acylation of 6‑APA); removes the aryl side chain and reduces complexity.
2) If building the bicyclic core, disconnect the β‑lactam bond (N–C=O) into ketene + imine precursors — retrosynthetic transform: Staudinger [2+2] cycloaddition. Rationale: the β‑lactam is strained and can be formed by a convergent ketene–imine cycloaddition; this simplifies the fused bicyclic framework into two simpler fragments (imine derived from thiazolidine/cysteine fragment and a ketene from the acyl piece).' core_structure_analysis="The core (scaffold) is a penam: a bicyclic system composed of a four‑membered β‑lactam fused to a five‑membered thiazolidine (β‑lactam–thiazolidine fused ring). This fused bicyclic penam defines the molecule's chemical identity and is the topologically central element. The two most chemically characteristic features are the strained β‑lactam (reactive, susceptible to ring opening/formations) and the N‑linked acyl side chain (a typical modifiable penicillin substituent). These features guide the strategic disconnections above." strategic_bond_disconnection='Primary: cleavage of the N–C(=O) amide bond between the penam nitrogen and the phenoxyacetyl side chain (gives 6‑APA + phenoxyacetic acid/activated derivative). Secondary: cleavage of the β‑lactam N–C(=O) bond to give an imine (from the thiazolidine fragment) and a ketene (acyl fragment) for a Staudinger retrosynthetic step.' reaction_type='1) Amide coupling / N‑acylation
2) [2+2] Cycloaddition (ketene + imine → β‑lactam)' reaction_name='1) N‑Acylation (Schotten–Baumann / acyl chloride acylation of 6‑APA)
2) Staudinger [2+2] ketene–imine cycloaddition (β‑lactam formation)' description='Retrosynthetic plan for the given SMILES (a penicillin derivative). Core idea: disconnect the N‑acyl side chain to reveal 6‑aminopenicillanic acid (6‑APA) and then, if needed, disconnect the strained β‑lactam to simpler ketene + imine precursors (Staudinger approach).'

Plan for CC(=O)O[C@H]1C(=O)[C@]2(C)[C@@H](O)C[C@H]3OC[C@@]3(OC(=O)C)C2[C@H](OC(=O)c4ccccc4)[C@]5(O)C[C@H](OC(=O)[C@H](O)[C@@H](NC(=O)c6ccccc6)c7ccccc7)C(=C1C5(C)C)C: strategy_index='1 = global ester disconnection (highest priority, easiest/most simplifying); 2 = spiro‑ketal opening (reveals core assembly precursor); 3 = amide disconnection (late‑stage installation in forward synthesis).' core_structure_analysis='The molecule is built on a highly oxygenated polycyclic spiro/bridged ring scaffold: a fused bicyclic/tricyclic oxy‑framework containing a spiro‑ketal/acetals motif (multiple C–O–C linkages) with an exocyclic C=C at a bridgehead and several tertiary/secondary alcohol stereocenters. This central spiro‑ketal/bridged polyether core is the defining scaffold (the aglycone) and the various aryl and acyl groups are peripheral ester/amide appendages.' strategic_bond_disconnection='Primary strategic disconnection: cleavage of peripheral ester bonds (C–O–C(=O)Ar and C–O–C(=O)Me) to unmask the core polyol. Secondary: cleavage of the spiro‑ketal C–O bonds (open ketal to carbonyl + diol). Tertiary: cleavage of the amide N–C(=O) bond to separate the benzamide fragment.' reaction_type='1) Ester hydrolysis / esterification. 2) Acetal/ketal formation/cleavage (acid‑catalyzed). 3) Amide bond formation / hydrolysis (peptide coupling).' reaction_name='1) Saponification / ester hydrolysis  (retro) — forward: Steglich esterification (DCC/DMAP) or acyl chloride coupling.  2) Spiro‑ketal (acetal) formation/cleavage — forward: acid‑catalyzed ketalization/acetalization.  3) Amide coupling / amide disconnection — forward: amide bond formation (HATU/DIC or EDC/HOBt)' description='Retrosynthetic outline (concise):
1) Global ester disconnection: hydrolyse the three benzoate/acetate esters and the methyl acetate to reveal the highly oxygenated polyol spiro‑ketal core (aglycone) plus simple carboxylic acids (benzoic acid, acetic acid, and the chiral hydroxy‑acid fragment). This dramatically reduces complexity by removing three (or more) aromatic acyl substituents.
2) Spiro‑ketal disconnection: open the central spiro/bridged ketal to a dialdehyde/ketone + vicinal diol (or hydroxyketone) precursor — i.e. retrosynthetic removal of the C–O bonds that form the ketal. This reveals a simpler linear or bicyclic carbonyl‑diol precursor that can be assembled and then cyclized stereoselectively.
3) Amide disconnection: cleave the N–C(=O) bond of the N‑benzoyl anilide to give the free amine (an amino‑diaryl fragment) and benzoyl chloride/benzoic acid. This splits the peptide/amide appendage into two simple building blocks.
Overall sequencing: start retrosynthetically by removing peripheral esters (lowest stability, easiest simplification), then open the spiroketal to the carbonyl + diol precursor, and finally disconnect the amide to give simple aryl carboxylic/amine fragments.'

Plan for CO[C@H]1[C@@H](C[C@@H]2CN3CCC4=C([C@H]3C[C@@H]2[C@@H]1C(=O)OC)NC5=C4C=CC(=C5)OC)OC(=O)C6=CC(=C(C(=C6)OC)OC)OC: strategy_index='1' core_structure_analysis='The defining scaffold is a bridged, benzo‑fused azabicyclic polycycle (a tetrahydroisoquinoline/protoberberine‑like core) containing a tertiary amine and several contiguous stereocenters. This fused heterocycle is the topological and functional heart of the molecule; the peripheral aromatic trimethoxybenzoate and several methoxy substituents are decorating groups.' strategic_bond_disconnection='Primary: cleavage of the exocyclic ester bond linking the polycyclic aliphatic stereocenter (the oxygen-bearing ring junction) to the 3,4,5-trimethoxybenzoyl fragment. Secondary disconnection: break the C–C/C–N bond that closes the benzo‑fused azabicyclic ring system to reveal a β‑arylethylamine (or amino‑alcohol) precursor — retrosynthetic Pictet–Spengler/Mannich disconnection.' reaction_type='Esterification / Acylation (Steglich or EDC coupling) and Pictet–Spengler (intramolecular iminium cyclization)' reaction_name='Ester disconnection (retrosynthetic cleavage) followed by Pictet–Spengler/Mannich annulation (forward: esterification & Pictet–Spengler)' description='Step 1 (most strategic, simplifies complexity): cleave the ester that links the complex polycyclic alcohol to the 3,4,5‑trimethoxybenzoate. Retrosynthetically this gives two simple precursors: the polycyclic alcohol (the core tetracyclic amine scaffold bearing a free hydroxyl) and 3,4,5‑trimethoxybenzoic acid. This disconnection is chemically reasonable because esters are readily disconnected under hydrolytic/retrosynthetic thinking and, in the forward sense, can be assembled by standard acylation methods (Steglich DCC/DMAP or EDC/HOBt) or activated acid chlorides. Step 2 (second key simplification): open the heterocyclic annulation by disconnecting the bond formed in the final ring‑closing cyclization that creates the benzo‑fused azabicycle. The core can be assembled from a simpler β‑arylethylamine (or amino‑alcohol) and an aldehyde/ketone via an acid‑catalyzed Pictet–Spengler (or intramolecular Mannich/Pictet) cyclization to form the tetrahydroisoquinoline framework. This approach converts a complex, highly functionalized fused ring system into two accessible building blocks (a substituted phenethylamine fragment and a carbonyl partner) and explains the origin of the tertiary amine via subsequent N‑alkylation or reductive amination if needed. Together these disconnections (ester cleavage + annulation disconnection) maximize simplification and map onto reliable forward reactions (acylation and Pictet–Spengler) commonly used in alkaloid synthesis.'
